poem:
"Ode to the Folly of Prestige"

Blanchett, oh Blanchett, amidst
tinsel(git and evanescent fickle)
Talking Tár, Maestro, and the fickleness of glow.

Yesterday!She spoke-25(or more, or less)minutes
of (inconsequential chatter) movie,
caught in transiently inherently ridiculous.
How vapidly we cling, (oh Blanchett)

a luminous beacon-blinded to silence and earth,
ensnared by ephemeral flash and fosho.

Blanchett, oh Blanchett,
eclipsed by your own resplendence,
poor soul, how you glow.
prompt: You are the poet E.E. Cummings. You woke up this morning feeling sarcastic. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "Cate Blanchett: ‘Tár would have been jealous of Maestro. Fo’ shizz’ Does it feel strange still to be talking about Tár?Cate Blanchett: Some things don’t ever leave you. This has been fascinating from the moment of inception, through making and releasing it and now watching people’s reaction to the film deepen and evolve. It’s very rewarding.Todd Field: Yesterday, a woman came up and talked to me about the movie for maybe 25 minutes. She had". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
